text: Great to see old friends & meet new ones — like Fifi — at #AEFP2024! Until next year 👋

Conferences can be great for catching up with new work and old friends. They can also trigger social and professional anxiety. My conference mantra is: Don’t compare yourself to others; focus on “What can I learn, and what can I contribute?” #AEFP2024
My favorite type of conversation to overhear at CVG: “she thought we were in Ohio… but really, we’re in Kentucky.”
This week, I’m blaming that on the daylight savings time change

I'll be at #AEFP2024 to present promising evidence regarding the effect of RP funding on school climate measures and student achievement 4/4 virtual.oxfordabstracts.com#/event/4542/...

Glad to see this out! 
➡️ In the context of suspension restrictions, funding for RPs did not provide differential reductions in suspension rates. 
➡️ Importantly, this does *not* mean RPs are ineffective! We have credible evidence that they are beneficial for other key outcomes. 1/4

Our program is small, with lots of student-faculty interaction, and we have a great track record of sending students to high-paying jobs and strong PhD programs, including Johns Hopkins (econ), Notre Dame (econ), and NYU (public policy) since I've been here.

I'm a little late this year, but still want to give my annual plug for our 1-year econ MA program here at Miami! miamioh.edu/fsb/graduate...

We will consider apps until June 1, so if you have a great student whose postgrad plans aren't panning out the way they hoped, send them our way!

Such a treat to visit the Bates College econ department today and spend time with my good friend & coauthor Austin Smith!

And a bonus: my youngest sister (Bates ‘24), parents (Bates ‘85), and grandmother (lifelong Mainer) came to see my seminar. ❤️
Definitely!
Glad to see this great paper coauthored by my Miami colleagues out in ReStat. Congrats, @@148944 @@326485!

Want to highlight a new WP by my former Miami MA student, @@1573317. They find that NYC's ban on school suspensions led to an increase in students being identified for special ed. Very cool paper with big policy implications! edworkingpapers.com/ai24-902
Busing students to the suburbs has benefits for those being bused and no downside for the rest. Read more about this great work from Tufts own Elizabeth Setren www.wbur.org/news/2024/01...
First real snow of the season here in Cincy! ❄️

Please consider submitting to this conference on access and equity in education in memory of Rodney Andrews, who sadly passed away last year. The conference will focus on access and equity in education and labor market outcomes. Submissions can be made at tinyurl.com/2s3j6nkr. Deadline Feb. 9th.

4 generations of family Christmas stockings ❤️💚

Working through things by creating a list of 4 year universities that have announced budget cuts. Culling google news to find them. docs.google.com/spreadsheets...

Students! Do not uncritically use Stata's default output for sum to make tables in papers!

Ex: the min & max may not be interesting stats for the reader. And when they are interesting, often a distribution figure would be better.

And don't get me started on "obs" columns where every # is the same.

v interesting writeup today in the NBER Digest on new research about the motherhood penalty worldwide 📉📈
www.nber.org/digest/20231...
Ever since they got rid of American Fact Finder (RIP), it’s taken me forever to figure out how to download what I want… if I can even figure it out at all.

This year Boston College’s Economics Department is hiring TWO more Professors of the Practice (PoPs), focusing on folks who teach Principles and a great elective, or Stats/Metrics and a great elective (of their choosing). 2/x

Application portal for the 2024 AEA Summer Program now open. The program prepares students for the rigors of graduate studies through two months of intensive training in microeconomics, math, econometrics, and research methods. www.aeaweb.org/about-aea/co.... #EconSky
This Thanksgiving, I'm thankful for all the women in Econ who persevere. Y'all are killing it. 🙌🏻 I see you. I'm glad you're here. You're making this field better. Keep up the great work.
Just don’t tell us you’d love to live in a bustling beachside city when we are actually the Miami in… southwest Ohio.
A+ for creativity, for sure!
In Econ, when you are applying to like 120+ places, best to tailor cover letters for places where you really want to go but where it’s not the case that everyone else really wants to go there too.

I think the answer depends on who’s reading you app. 😅

FWIW, in our R2 dept., tailored cover letters are probably most helpful when we think you are out of reach, but you provide a compelling reason why you want our particular job. But certainly not a necessary condition to get an interview!
My comment from a hiring committee at a non-R1 institution: cover letters matter.
Are you trying to get an academic job with a strong teaching focus? Are you advising someone who is trying to get such a job? Come to session 1.B.01 at Southerns on Saturday morning at 10:45!

Yeah, it's one of those things that could be true at some institutions, but perhaps not nationally. Business degrees have actually not been growing that quickly over the past decade. Health & engineering much more so. nces.ed.gov/programs/coe...

Also, FWIW, I think Miami is an outlier in terms of entrepreneurship  being a popular major. Less than 1% of business-related bachelor's degrees nationally are in entrepreneurship... though some might be classified as general business admin. 

nces.ed.gov/ipeds/Summar...

One could fairly easily get this in IPEDS using data on degrees conferred by detailed CIP code. 😊

Relatedly, @@326755 has a great paper on the proliferation of majors at US colleges! drive.google.com/file/d/1ErLt...

Interested to hear how it goes!
Perusall automatically does the grading, but you can toggle with the settings to reward time spent actively reading, high-quality comments, responses to other students’ comments, etc.

I have them complete all assigned readings there & they count towards their class participation grade. Having some points attached seems to increase engagement and they leave some really insightful comments and answer each others questions! I can also jump in and answer questions, which I like.
👇 totally agree! Perusall has been great for having my students read & engage with empirical papers.
Once again had an amazing @@184297 #APPAM2023 engaging with excellent research, catching up with friends, and making new connections. Til next year!

Tip for any #2023APPAM travelers with TSA pre-check, flying Delta: if you opt-in to Delta’s digital ID, you can use a separate security line at ATL. It was very speedy this morning! www.delta.com/us/en/check-...

Really honored to be presenting my research tomorrow at #2023APPAM on a panel in memory of Rodney Andrews

So much of what I do is inspired by his work and the path he set — “Standing on the shoulders of giants” is an understatement
Unfortunately, no. Too hard to do them both back to back!

Headed to ATL for APPAM! (#APPAM2023? #2023APPAM? Do we have a hashtag on here?)

I am starting a new project with Mackenzie Alston on the academic job market. Hoping to informally chat with 5 econ PhDs and 5 PhDs from psych, sociology, or polisci who graduated last year. If you're available for a 15-minute Zoom convo in Nov., please DM or email mjalston@illinois.edu!

I'm so thankful that my sister is (physically) okay, but continue to be absolutely devastated for her community and all of Maine -- a state near & dear to my family. 💔 

In addition to supporting the victims & their families, let's all continue to advocate for gun reform in this country.

I've seen data on gendered retention patterns before, but the thing that sticks out to me here is how they found that women were more likely than men to feel "pushed" out of their position, and men were more likely than women to feel "pulled" toward a better opportunity.

Thinking about how people like Claudia Goldin paved the way for what I got to witness tonight: 4 of our Women In Econ seniors eloquently discussing their in-progress theses and giving advice to the next cohort of undergrad women who want to get involved in research.

The future is bright! 😎

Thinking this morning about how all women in Economics have gone through so much shit and worked so damn hard to get where they (we) are. 

Cheers to a trailblazer, Claudia Goldin, today, who helped make it a little easier for all of us!

Newish paper with Haowen Zheng (1st author): gender differences in field of study account for about 36% of the segregation of male and female college graduates across occupations. 

Implies that 64% is unrelated to field, get-women-in-STEM programs not a panacea.

read.dukeupress.edu/demography/a...

Yeah, you can get the data (individual-level, surprisingly detailed!) through 2010 if you create an account, which is free. But anything after that, you need to submit a data request and pay a fee… The public reports on their website are pretty good though!

You can get the tabulations from 1966 to 2015 in the appendix of this report: www.heri.ucla.edu/monographs/5... (starts around pg. 68).

The HERI survey data has a lot of cool stuff in it! I’m in the early stages of using it for a project.

Just made the move from EconTwitter, so it's intro time! 👋

I'm a PhD candidate at UW-Madison. My research interests are in the economics of education and education policy (mostly higher ed), labor economics, and public economics.

Oh, and a shameless plug that i am on the job market this year 😉
PSA: IPEDS just released the newest year of data for institutional characteristics, enrollment, and completions. Get it before the government shuts down and data access becomes uncertain!
AEFP is pleased to offer financial support to students and policymakers/practitioners to attend our annual conference. Learn more about these programs: aefpweb.org/travel

Everyone, follow Emma! Not only does she say way too nice things about me, she is a fabulous former student who is now RAing at the Chicago Fed and applying to PhD programs this fall! Keep your eye out for her. 👀
🥺🥺🥺 easy when you have great students!
One of my favorite things about EconTwitter was getting to know a little bit about peoples’ lives, interests, hobbies, etc., so I hope we keep that going here!
Also, in non-econ content, I was a gymnast 🤸🏼‍♀️ in my past life, so if #gymternetsky ever takes off, you’ll catch some posts about that from time to time!

Okay, intro time! I'm Riley. 👋 

I'm an assistant professor in the econ 📈📉 department at Miami University (yes, yes, that one in Ohio). 

I research the economics of education, especially higher ed. I also like teaching & thinking about how we educate the next generation of economists!

Hi everyone, especially recent converts!

I've been here a bit but maybe a new intro makes sense...

I'm Mike Lipsitz, an economist 📈📉 at the FTC studying ways firms influence competition (especially in labor markets, like noncompetes) and how policy might help. Looking forward to this migration!
